questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 6-day history of gradually worsening right knee pain. The pain is exacerbated by movement and kneeling. There is no pain at rest and no history of trauma to the knee. He is concerned because his soccer tryouts are in a few days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild swelling and tenderness to palpation of the right anterior, superior tibia. Extension of the right knee against resistance reproduces the knee pain; flexion is limited by pain. There is no local erythema or effusion of the right knee. A lateral view of an x-ray of his right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Impingement of the infrapatellar fat pad
Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle
Avulsion fracture of the proximal tibia

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Impingement of the infrapatellar fat pad between the femoral condyle and the patella may occur if the fat pad becomes swollen secondary to direct trauma, chronic irritation, or hyperextension injury. Patients present with anterior knee pain inferior to the patella, which is typically exacerbated by sprinting or squatting. Examination may show mild swelling and pain on palpation on either side of the patellar tendon (equivalent to position of the fat pad), but is otherwise unremarkable. Pain over the insertion point of the patellar tendon (proximal anterior tibia), as experienced by this patient, does not occur.

B) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the infrapatellar bursa (i.e., infrapatellar bursitis) can be caused by trauma, overuse, or systemic diseases. It manifests with pain that worsens on kneeling and movement (extension/flexion), reduced mobility, as well as localized swelling, erythema, and warmth. The diagnosis is typically established clinically, and, since bursas are not radiopaque, radiography is rarely used other than to rule out fracture. This patient's x-ray findings suggest another underlying cause of his symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Osteoid osteomas are benign bone tumors seen typically in individuals 10–30 years old. The tumor can develop in any bone, but most commonly affects the metaphyses and diaphyses of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia, humerus) or the spine. The characteristic clinical feature is a persistent, intense, aching pain localized to the site of the lesion that worsens at night. Physical examination often shows pain on palpation that is not exacerbated by movement, unless intracapsular lesions occur. Since this patient has no history of pain at rest or at night, and extension/flexion elicits pain, osteoid osteoma is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Chondromalacia patellae can be due to trauma or overuse and affected individuals (often young adults) report vague discomfort of the anterior knee, which is worsened by activity, especially while climbing stairs. Physical examination may show crepitus of the knee. X-ray is usually normal in early chondromalacia patellae since bones are unaffected.

E) CORRECT:

Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle occurs in Osgood Schlatter disease, which typically affects adolescent athletes. Overuse (e.g., sports that involve running and jumping) leads to the patellar tendon exerting excessive strain on the tibial tuberosity, which is not yet fully ossified in adolescents and is thus susceptible to detachment. Patients typically present with anterior knee pain localized to the tibial tubercle. Visible swelling of the proximal tibia may also be present. X-ray is usually not required for diagnosis, but may be helpful to rule out differential diagnoses, especially in cases of atypical presentation (e.g., history of trauma, nocturnal pain, pain at rest). This patient's age, history, and x-ray findings of fragmentation and irregularity of the tibial tubercle are all indicative of Osgood Schlatter disease.

Osgood Schlatter disease is usually self-limited. Treatment is therefore primarily conservative, consisting of rest, ice, stretching exercises, and NSAIDs.

F) INCORRECT:

Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) commonly occurs in males 10–20 years old and is most likely caused by mechanical stress and/or repetitive trauma. The condition manifests with diffuse joint pain during activities and progressive joint stiffness with locking or catching of the joint. On physical examination, range of motion is intact, though palpation of the femoral condyles in the flexed knee elicits pain. OCD can be ruled out since this patient presents with pain over the proximal tibial and not the femoral condyles. Moreover, patients with OCD would have a crescent-shaped radiolucency on the medial femoral condyle, whereas this patient's abnormality is on the tibial tuberosity.

G) INCORRECT:

Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS) is a common overuse injury of the knee caused by repetitive flexion and extension of the knee. Clinically, the condition manifests with sharp pain at the lateral knee when the foot hits the ground while running and constant, dull pain at rest. Physical examination elicits pain if pressure is applied to the lateral femoral epicondyle during passive flexion of the leg. Although this patient has likely been running frequently and has an increased risk for overuse injury, his symptoms are not consistent with this diagnosis. Moreover, radiographs in patients with ITBS usually appear normal.

H) INCORRECT:

While an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle can also manifest with tenderness over the proximal tibia that is exacerbated by movement, it is generally the result of acute trauma, such as forced flexion against a contracted quadriceps muscle (e.g., coming down from a high jump during basketball). Furthermore, an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle would result in severe pain even at rest, as well as effusion of the knee joint. This patient's x-ray shows fragmentation, not avulsion fracture, of the proximal tibia.

This patient's condition may predispose him to developing an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle.
questions.hint: In a physically active adolescent, anterior knee pain that is worse with activity and is reproducible with extension against resistance should raise concern for Osgood Schlatter disease.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of pain in his right knee for the past week. The pain is exacerbated by jogging and climbing up stairs. He has no history of trauma to the knee. He is otherwise healthy. He is an active member of his school's gymnastics team. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows a tender swelling at the proximal tibia; range of motion is full. Knee extension against resistance causes pain in the anterior proximal tibia. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee shows anterior tibial soft tissue swelling with fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Open reduction of the tibial tuberosity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While steroid injections have been used for many years for the treatment of tendinopathies, recent studies have shown that their long-term benefit is questionable and that they can adversely affect soft tissue, including the injured tendon. Regardless, it would not help the necrotic bone of Osgood Schlatter disease heal. Additionally, an injection intended to treat tendinopathies should be paratendinous, rather than intratendinous, to minimize damage to an already inflamed tendon.

B) CORRECT:

First-line treatment in patients with Osgood Schlatter disease is a combination of rest, ice, and NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen). If this combination is not effective, immobilization can be attempted. Surgical excision of the fragmented tibial tubercle (and any other ossicles found in the area of the tendon) is reserved for refractory cases.

A fragmented tibial tubercle must be differentiated from an avulsion fracture of the tubercle, which requires surgical treatment.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (lateral view) of an adolescent with a painful swelling below the knee

The fragmented appearance of the tibial tuberosity (fragments indicated by green overlay) with overlying soft tissue swelling (indicated by arrow) and thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) supports a diagnosis of apophysitis at the patellar tendon insertion (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

C) INCORRECT:

Joint aspiration is a very important diagnostic tool for confirming suspected septic arthritis, but septic arthritis is unlikely in a patient with neither fever nor local erythema and warmth. Additionally, the pain is primarily located in the area of the proximal tibia, whereas septic arthritis manifests in the joint itself.

D) INCORRECT:

Open reduction is used to treat avulsion fractures of the tibial tuberosity, which is both a differential diagnosis of Osgood Schlatter disease and a possible complication of it. In patients with avulsion fractures, the quadriceps tendon, which inserts in the area of the tibial tuberosity, is typically retracted. This retraction elevates the patella, which is embedded in the quadriceps tendon, and leads to decreased quadriceps strength. This patient does not have reduced quadriceps strength, and the x-ray only shows fragmentation, not avulsion fracture, of the tuberosity.

E) INCORRECT:

Excision of the tibial tuberosity may be considered if the patient had already received extensive conservative treatment. Surgical excision of the tuberosity and/or of any ossicles in the area of the tendon is reserved for cases refractory to conservative measures, and is generally only performed after the proximal tibial growth plate has closed.

F) INCORRECT:

Bone biopsy is used for the diagnosis of suspected bone tumors such as osteosarcoma, which tends to occur proximal and distal to the knee joint. Pain that worsens with activity and tenderness to palpation would also be consistent with this diagnosis. However, in the case of osteosarcoma, x-ray typically shows osteolysis, sunburst appearance, and/or Codman triangle, none of which is present here.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (lateral view) of an 18 year-old patient with pain

A mixed lytic and sclerotic lesion showing a permeative pattern of destruction involves the distal femoral metaphysis and metadiaphysis. It is accompanied by a Codman triangle with aggressive periosteal reaction that extends into the soft tissues.

Although biopsy is required for a definitive diagnosis, the location and appearance of the lesion in combination with the patient's age suggest osteosarcoma. The distal femur is a particularly common location for osteosarcoma.

G) INCORRECT:

Cast immobilization for 6 weeks can be attempted in cases that are refractory to other conservative measures, but it should not be attempted as an initial treatment.
questions.hint: In a physically active adolescent, a history of nontraumatic knee pain associated with swelling of the proximal tibia that worsens with exercise and is reproducible with extension against resistance is strongly suggestive of Osgood Schlatter disease.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 1-month history of pain in her right knee. She is a competitive volleyball player and has missed several games recently due to pain. Examination shows swelling distal to the right knee joint on the anterior surface of the proximal tibia; there is no overlying warmth or deformity. Extension of the right knee against resistance is painful. Which of the following structures is attached to the affected anterior tibial area?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) connects the lateral femoral condyle and the anteromedial tibia within the knee joint. Sprains and tears of the ACL occur suddenly following injuries with a twisting mechanism and present with knee pain and instability. Examination typically shows anterior knee laxity (positive Lachman test).

B) CORRECT:

The patellar ligament connects the patella to the tibial tuberosity and allows for full extension of the knee via the quadriceps muscle. Osgood-Schlatter disease arises due to overuse of the quadriceps muscle during a period of growth (adolescence), which puts excessive strain on the attachment of the patellar ligament at the tibial tuberosity, resulting in painful inflammation and avascular necrosis. Patients present with pain during quadriceps contraction.
Image Description:

Left knee of a 31-year-old patient

The tibial tuberosity has remained prominent in adulthood (red overlay) secondary to Osgood-Schlatter disease in adolescence.

C) INCORRECT:

Although injury to the quadriceps tendon can also present with anterior knee pain that is worse during extension of the knee against resistance, the tendon connects the quadriceps femoris muscle to the superior aspect of the patella, not the tibial tuberosity.

D) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the iliotibial band (ITB) is a common cause of knee pain secondary to excessive running, jumping, or overstretching. However, it typically causes sharp pain along the lateral side of the knee, as the ITB inserts at the lateral condyle of the tibia, not the tibial tuberosity.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic overuse of the pes anserinus tendon, which connects the sartorius, gracilis, and semitendinosus muscles to the anteromedial aspect of the tibia, can cause pes anserine bursitis. Patients present with medial knee pain and swelling. Extension of the knee against resistance would not elicit pain.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease, a common cause of anterior knee pain in growing adolescents, especially those involved in running and jumping sports.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of gradually worsening pain in the left knee. He says that the pain is worse with exercise and that he cannot play soccer well anymore. There is no pain at rest and no history of trauma to the knee. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows tenderness to palpation of the left anterior and superior tibia and a slightly prominent tibial tubercle. Extension of the left knee against resistance reproduces the knee pain; flexion is limited by pain. There is no local erythema or effusion of the left knee. Examination of the right knee is normal. The lateral view of an x-ray of his left knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely course of this patient's disease?

choices.text: Full recovery with popliteal cyst formation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gradual deterioration with functional limitation occurs in osteoarthritis, which is a complication of several conditions of the knee, including recurrent patellar dislocation. Although patellar dislocation manifests with knee pain and restricted range of motion, physical examination would show a laterally displaced patella, joint effusion, and erythema. Osgood-Schlatter disease, on the other hand, does not result in progressive functional limitation.
Image Description:

The localized swelling in the distal upper thigh is the patella, which is laterally dislocated. Lateral patellar dislocation is much more common than medial dislocation.

B) INCORRECT:

Popliteal cyst formation is a complication of meniscus tear that manifests with weight-bearing pain, which is exacerbated by physical activity. An MRI scan, rather than an x-ray, is needed to establish the diagnosis. Osgood-Schlatter disease is not associated with popliteal cyst formation.
Image Description:

Dorsomedial view of the knee with swelling in the popliteal fossa indicating popliteal cyst (arrow).

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent disease with periodic exacerbation is commonly seen in seropositive polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA), which may manifest with knee pain and restricted range of motion and commonly occurs in young individuals (peak incidence: 9–12 years of age). This patient does not have morning stiffness or extra-articular manifestations (e.g., fever, uveitis, rash) of seropositive JIA. Osgood-Schlatter disease, on the other hand, does not manifest with periodic exacerbations.
Image Description:

– Oligoarthritis: asymmetrical oligoarthritis involving ≤ 4 joints (within 6 months of onset); associated with iridocyclitis
– Seronegative polyarthritis: asymmetrical or symmetrical oligoarthritis; associated with iridocyclitis
– Seropositive polyarthritis: symmetrical polyarthritis involving ≥ 5 joints (within 6 months of onset)

D) CORRECT:

In a physically active adolescent, anterior knee pain that worsens with activity and is reproducible with extension against resistance should raise concern for Osgood-Schlatter disease. Overuse (e.g., due to sports that involve sprinting and jumping) leads to traction apophysitis of the tibial tuberosity, which is not yet fully ossified, making it susceptible to detachment and callous formation. Osgood-Schlatter disease is usually self-limited and complete remission is expected at skeletal maturity with the closure of the proximal tibial growth plate, which occurs between 14–18 years of age. Some patients may have persistent pain and ongoing prominence of the tibial tubercle. In very rare cases, patients may develop genu recurvatum.

Treatment is primarily conservative, consisting of rest, ice, stretching and strengthening exercises, and NSAIDs.

E) INCORRECT:

Genu recurvatum (i.e., hyperextension of the knee) is a very rare complication of Osgood-Schlatter disease. Another disease course is more likely in this patient.
questions.hint: The lateral x-ray of the knee shows avascular osteonecrosis of the tibial patellar tendon insertion, which is consistent with Osgood-Schlatter disease.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy who participates in organized sports year-round reports a one-year history of increasingly severe bilateral knee pain.
The pain varies in severity depending on his activity level and appears to have been exacerbated by an unusually intense series of basketball games in the past week. It is most localized to the anterior inferior aspect of both knees, is aching in quality, and is typically accompanied by mild swelling. The patient has not attempted any kind of treatment for the pain.
On examination, he has prominent, bilateral tibial tuberosities that are mildly tender to palpation. His range of motion and strength at the knees is normal. His extensor mechanism is intact, and all his ligamentous examinations are normal. His neurovascular examination is also normal.
In addition to icing and avoidance of aggravating activities, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Order MRI of both lower extremities
Recommend a brief trial of over-the-counter ibuprofen as needed
Prescribe high-dose ibuprofen three times daily for at least 2 weeks
Recommend dexamethasone iontophoresis to the patellar tendon
Inject dexamethasone into both knee joints

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease is a clinical diagnosis, and imaging is typically not indicated, particularly when the symptoms are bilateral, as in this case, making other conditions such as a fracture or ligamentous injury less likely. If an MRI is obtained, it may reveal inflammation of the infrapatellar bursa as well as some soft-tissue swelling around the tibial tuberosity.

B) CORRECT:

This patient probably has Osgood-Schlatter disease, a common overuse injury in active, skeletally immature individuals. Chronic tensile stress, exerted through the patellar tendon on the tibial tuberosity from running and jumping sports, leads to tibial tubercle apophysitis in active adolescents. The condition is more common in boys than girls, is almost always self-limited, and resolves with skeletal maturity.

The recommended initial treatment plan for symptoms of Osgood-Schlatter disease is a conservative one involving activity modification, quadriceps and hamstring stretching, ice, and an over-the-counter nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) as needed. Referral to physical therapy may also be an option if these more conservative measures are not successful.

Complete avoidance of activity is typically unnecessary and can be detrimental to the patient’s conditioning.

Prescription-dose NSAIDs are associated with a high incidence of adverse effects in this age group and are therefore not indicated. High-dose ibuprofen, in particular, may lead to gastritis and other adverse effects.

Glucocorticoid injections (e.g., with dexamethasone) and iontophoresis are not recommended in the treatment of Osgood-Schlatter disease because they can lead to premature physeal closure.

Surgery (osteotomy) is indicated only for the rare cases of Osgood-Schlatter disease that do not respond adequately to conservative treatment.

Osgood-Schlatter disease is a clinical diagnosis, and imaging is typically not indicated, particularly when the symptoms are bilateral, as in this case, making other conditions such as a fracture or ligamentous injury less likely. If an MRI is obtained, it may reveal inflammation of the infrapatellar bursa as well as some soft-tissue swelling around the tibial tuberosity.

Key learning point: The best treatment plan for an active school-age boy with bilateral tibial tuberosity pain includes icing, quadriceps and hamstring stretching, avoidance of aggravating activities, and use of over-the-counter nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication.

C) INCORRECT:

Prescription-dose NSAIDs are associated with a high incidence of adverse effects in this age group and are therefore not indicated. High-dose ibuprofen, in particular, may lead to gastritis and other adverse effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid iontophoresis is not recommended in the treatment of Osgood-Schlatter disease because it can lead to premature physeal closure.

E) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid injections (e.g., with dexamethasone) are not recommended in the treatment of Osgood-Schlatter disease because they can lead to premature physeal closure.

questions.text:
A healthy 11-year-old girl who is active in soccer and basketball reports a 2-week history of anterior right-knee pain with no known preceding trauma, injury, or illness. She has no knee-joint effusion or ligamentous laxity. She has tenderness and swelling over the anterior aspect of the proximal tibia without a limp.
A radiograph of the knee is obtained (figure).
What is the most appropriate next step in care for this patient?

choices.text: Arrange for MRI of the knee
Inject lidocaine into the prepatellar bursa
Refer for iontophoresis of cortisone to the patellar tendon

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the knee is not indicated in a child with a normal ligament examination and no history of trauma or knee effusion.

B) INCORRECT:

Children with Osgood-Schlatter disease should continue to exercise within the limits of their pain. Immobilizing the knee (as one might for an acute traumatic injury) is not recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient’s symptoms are not plausibly caused by prepatellar bursitis, so injection of lidocaine into that site would not be effective.

D) CORRECT:

The presence of tenderness over the tibial tubercle and radiographic evidence of fragmentation of the tibial tubercle in the absence of trauma or infection suggests that this patient has apophysitis of the tibial tubercle, or Osgood-Schlatter disease.

Apophysitis of the tibial tubercle is the most common overuse injury in adolescent athletes. Although it is most frequently seen in boys, the prevalence among girls has increased as their participation in sports has increased. The injury typically occurs during a growth spurt (usually ages 9–14) and is often associated with running and jumping sports. It involves repetitive microtrauma at the site of the distal attachment of the patellar tendon to the fibrous portion of the tibial tubercle. Gradual onset of anterior knee pain — with tenderness, swelling, and prominence of the tibial tubercle — is common.

In patients with apophysitis of the tibial tubercle, radiography of the knee typically reveals open growth plates, anterior soft-tissue swelling, and widening or fragmentation of the tibial tubercle apophysis.

The appropriate initial treatment of a child with apophysitis of the tibial tubercle is ice, avoidance of painful activities, and use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication. Reassuring the child and the family that the disease is self-limiting and will resolve when the child stops growing is an important aspect of management.

Children with Osgood-Schlatter disease should continue to exercise within the limits of their pain. Immobilizing the knee (as one might for an acute traumatic injury) is not recommended.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management for Osgood-Schlatter disease is reassurance and supportive care.

E) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroid iontophoresis is not indicated to treat Osgood-Schlatter disease but may be performed to treat patellar tendinopathy (jumper's knee). Patellar tendinopathy can occur in adolescents involved in sports and can cause tenderness and a mild swelling over the anterior aspect of the proximal tibia (below the patella and above the tibial tuberosity), but fragmentation of the tibial tubercle is not expected in this condition.

There is no pain at rest and no history of trauma to the knee. He is concerned because his soccer tryouts are in a few days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Avulsion fracture of the proximal tibia

This patient's condition may predispose him to developing an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy presents with left knee pain that began soon after his school basketball season started. The pain worsens with running or jumping and improves with rest. Examination shows localized tenderness and swelling over the anterior aspect of the proximal tibia. Flexion at the knee exacerbates his discomfort, but the range of motion is normal. There is no joint effusion or instability.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prepatellar bursitis involves inflammation of the bursa anterior to the patella, often due to repetitive kneeling or direct trauma. The pain localizing to the anterior proximal tibia suggests an overuse injury involving the tibial tubercle, not the prepatellar region. The absence of prolonged kneeling or direct trauma further reduces the likelihood of prepatellar bursitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS) causes pain around or behind the patella, often exacerbated by activities stressing the patellofemoral joint, such as squatting. The localized tenderness and swelling over the anterior proximal tibia, near the tibial tubercle, and pain exacerbation with knee flexion indicate increased tension on the patellar tendon, differentiating it from PFPS.

C) CORRECT:

Osgood-Schlatter disease manifests in adolescents undergoing rapid growth, particularly those involved in sports. Repetitive stress on the patellar tendon leads to traction apophysitis at the tibial tubercle. This condition presents with localized pain, tenderness, and swelling over the anterior proximal tibia, exacerbated by activities like running or jumping. The patient's age and recent growth spurt predispose him to this overuse injury, where forces transmitted through the tendon cause microavulsions at the secondary ossification center, leading to inflammation and potential fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity.

Key learning point: Osgood-Schlatter disease is characterized by pain over the tibial tubercle in adolescents, often following a growth spurt and increased physical activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Patellar tendinitis typically presents with pain localized to the patellar tendon, near its insertion on the inferior pole of the patella. The focal tenderness and swelling over the anterior proximal tibia suggest involvement of the tibial apophyseal region, not the patellar tendon. Additionally, patellar tendinitis is more common in older athletes with mature tendons, whereas the patient's age suggests susceptibility to apophyseal stress injuries.
